Then, we need to define an interpretation function for the logical connectives. For example, we might define the interpretation function as follows:

* ¬: if the input is 1, the output is -1; if the input is -1, the output is 1; if the input is 0, the output is 0.
* ∧: if both inputs are 1, the output is 1; if both inputs are -1, the output is -1; otherwise, the output is 0.
* ∨: if either input is 1, the output is 1; if either input is -1, the output is -1; otherwise, the output is 0.
* →: if the first input is 0 or the second input is 1, the output is 1; if the first input is -1 or the second input is -1, the output is -1; otherwise, the output is 0.

With these definitions, we can use the interpretation function to assign truth-values to the propositions in the scenario. For example, we might assign the truth-value 1 to the proposition "M(walk(bar))" in one state and the truth-value 0 to the proposition "M(walk(bar))" in another state, depending on whether M is walking into a bar in those states.

I hope this revised version of the formal semantics helps to illustrate how logical matrices can be used to give a formal semantics for a scenario in which the strings "M" and "walk" are interpreted as logical connectives. Please let me know if you have any further questions!
